name: NewYorker
text: Raising a glass to The New Yorker legend—born ﬁve years before the founding of this magazine, and a contributor for the past 76—as he celebrates a milestone birthday. https://t.co/jt8gACc5Os

name: NewYorker
text: Kim Flitcroft’s 1995 documentary, “Tales from a Hard City,” tells the story of three young people aspiring to—and struggling to achieve—careers as performers, whose participation in the film is itself a means to their end. https://t.co/A9ahEYfLAT

name: NewYorker
text: “There’s still plenty of money to be made in art, or writing, or music,” @huahsu writes. “It’s just not being made by the creators.” https://t.co/lI4t8zxzqm

name: NewYorker
text: “Christ’s sakes, Casper. The advert was in the back pages of a gay magazine. For a houseboy. It’s hardly the employment office.” New fiction by @Doug_D_Stuart. https://t.co/UsRRMpZwQd

name: NewYorker
text:
The conceptual artist Bernadette Mayer's “Memory" may be from 1971, but its nostalgia for summers lost speaks uncannily to our moment.
https://t.co/XCyljN2AP8

name: NewYorker
text: “Someday you’ll feel thankful to your mother. But I want you to act thankful now.” Listen to Susan Choi read her new short story. https://t.co/vhMaLHgeOx

name: NewYorker
text: “I think that when people loot during a riot, they are solving a lot of the immediate problems that make their lives very, very hard," the author of “In Defense of Looting” says, in a conversation with @IChotiner. https://t.co/Lfdks4UzY9

name: NewYorker
text: In the pandemic, there will be an outdoor season and an indoor season, Paul Elie writes. Spring, summer, fall, and winter will be vestigial presences, which we encounter in music, poetry, and movies more than in our everyday lives. https://t.co/RkHKTokDci

name: NewYorker
text: It is simply incredible that many professional athletes have violated their contracts, withdrawn their labor, and demanded that this country change, @KeeangaYamahtta writes. https://t.co/oclpb6yGXs

name: NewYorker
text: In the spring, when the ice thaws in one of the northernmost villages in Greenland, some of the community's Inuit members begin to hunt narwhal. A new film peers into the tradition. Watch here. https://t.co/PbEdqdEI0V

name: NewYorker
text: Why were the killers of Ahmaud Arbery allowed to walk free until the shooting became a national scandal? And what does the failure to prosecute say about the power of district attorneys? #NewYorkerRadio https://t.co/V1kTQitv2g

name: NewYorker
text: In the summer and autumn of 2016, Nick Neely walked from San Diego to San Francisco Bay—a 650-mile trek. Neely's book about the journey, “Alta California,” touches on many layers of California’s fiendishly complex history. https://t.co/oH35JlWX0B

name: NewYorker
text:
We get a sense of what a warming globe feels like—each second, trapping the heat equivalent to four Hiroshima-sized bombs exploding—when we have a week like the one we just came through.
https://t.co/xpiBumtqoQ
